articles.title: Psychedelic drug ibogaine may treat PTSD by slowing brainwaves
articles.summary: In people with traumatic brain injury, administering the psychedelic drug ibogaine seems to slow down brainwaves, which may explain why it helps treat PTSD
articles.content:
In people with traumatic brain injury, administering the psychedelic drug ibogaine seems to slow down brainwaves, which may explain why it helps treat PTSD

The psychedelic drug ibogaine is extracted from iboga roots FARMER DODDS / Alamy

The psychedelic drug ibogaine slows down the brainwaves of people with traumatic brain injury, which may explain why it alleviates symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

Last year, a study found that ibogaine – a psychedelic substance derived from the African iboga plant – significantly improved mental and physical health in military veterans with traumatic brain injury. But it wasn’t clear how the drug produced these effects.

So, Jennifer Lissemore at Stanford University in California and her colleagues analysed brain scans of the original study’s 30 participants, all of whom were men from the US. The participants had received ibogaine at a dose of 12 milligrams per kilogram of body weight during a five-day stay at a treatment facility in Mexico. They also saw a therapist before and afterwards to prepare for and discuss their psychedelic treatment, and they had access to activities like yoga, massage and meditation.

Throughout the original study, researchers took electroencephalogram (EEG) recordings – which measure electrical activity in the brain – of the participants. These scans were collected two to three days before ibogaine therapy, 3.5 days afterwards and again one month later.

Comparing those EEG results, Lissemore and her colleagues found that, on average, faster brainwaves decreased in strength after ibogaine therapy, while slower ones did the opposite. For instance, days after taking ibogaine, the strength of gamma waves – the fastest type of brainwave – fell nearly 16 per cent, on average, in brain regions at the back of the head. These waves increased slightly in intensity one month later, but were still significantly lower than before participants had taken ibogaine.

Free newsletter Sign up to Health Check Expert insight and news on scientific developments in health, nutrition and fitness, every Saturday. Sign up to newsletter

Meanwhile, the intensity of slower, theta waves increased almost 17 per cent in the back of the brain and 13 per cent in the front of the brain 3.5 days after taking ibogaine. However, this difference was no longer significant one month later.

Lissemore believes the slowing of brainwaves may explain why ibogaine reduced PTSD symptoms for the majority of participants. “The slowing of brain activity went hand in hand with patients who were struggling with hyperarousal, hypervigilance and PTSD symptoms,” she says. “Those symptoms were improved drastically, and so one way to think of this slowing of brain activity is [as] a decrease in that hyperarousal that is a problem in PTSD.”

The temporary increase in slower theta waves also suggests that ibogaine induces neuroplasticity, or the brain’s ability to rewire itself. Previous studies in rodents have linked theta waves to plasticity in the brain, says Lissemore. By inducing short-term increases in theta waves, ibogaine may allow the brain to remodel itself in a way that improves mental health, she says.

“Ibogaine is basically targeting this very messy, restless brain and allowing it to kind of normalise,” says Conor Murray at the University of California, Los Angeles. “It ultimately gave [participants] a sense of peace of mind, in terms of putting their brains at ease.”

However, these results still don’t tell us how, exactly, ibogaine induces these changes in the brain, he notes.

Another issue is that the lack of a control group makes it impossible to disentangle the influence of other aspects of the treatment, such as therapy, says Lissemore. But these findings are still “an important first step towards understanding why this treatment might be so effective”, she says.
articles.reasoning: The article reports promising research on ibogaine, a psychedelic drug, showing potential to alleviate PTSD symptoms by slowing brainwaves and promoting neuroplasticity. This breakthrough offers hope for improved mental health treatments, especially for trauma-affected individuals, and highlights scientific progress in understanding brain function and therapy.

articles.personality_title_fr: L'ibogaïne montre un potentiel pour soulager le SSPT en ralentissant les ondes cérébrales
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Certaines personnes souffrant de lésions cérébrales traumatiques (LCT) développent un trouble de stress post-traumatique (SSPT), qui provoque stress et anxiété liés à un traumatisme passé. L'ibogaïne, un médicament psychédélique issu de la plante africaine iboga, a déjà montré une amélioration de la santé mentale chez des anciens combattants avec LCT, mais son mode d'action restait inconnu.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Des chercheurs de l'université Stanford ont étudié les scans cérébraux de 30 hommes avec LCT ayant reçu de l'ibogaïne lors d'un séjour de cinq jours au Mexique. Les participants ont aussi suivi une thérapie et participé à des activités comme le yoga et la méditation. L'activité cérébrale a été mesurée avant le traitement, quelques jours après, puis un mois plus tard grâce à l'EEG, qui enregistre les ondes cérébrales.

**Impact** – L'étude a montré qu'après l'ibogaïne, les ondes rapides appelées ondes gamma ralentissaient fortement, tandis que les ondes plus lentes, les ondes thêta, augmentaient temporairement. Ce ralentissement correspondait à une amélioration des symptômes du SSPT, comme l'hyperactivité et l'anxiété. L'augmentation des ondes thêta suggère que le cerveau pouvait se reconfigurer, un processus appelé neuroplasticité favorisant la guérison mentale.

**Étape suivante** – Les chercheurs cherchent à comprendre comment l'ibogaïne provoque ces changements cérébraux et à distinguer l'effet du médicament de celui de la thérapie et des autres activités. Des études contrôlées permettront de confirmer ses bienfaits et de guider des traitements sûrs.

**Résumé en une phrase** – L'ibogaïne pourrait soulager le SSPT en ralentissant les ondes cérébrales et en favorisant la capacité du cerveau à guérir, ouvrant la voie à de nouvelles approches pour les soins en santé mentale liés aux traumatismes.

articles.title: A new measure of health is revolutionising how we think about ageing
articles.summary: Life expectancy has increased dramatically over the past century, but our years of good health appear not to have kept pace. Now, a new lens on what it means to age well is reshaping our view of our golden years
articles.content:
Life expectancy has increased dramatically over the past century, but our years of good health appear not to have kept pace. Now, a new lens on what it means to age well is reshaping our view of our golden years

Stephan Schmitz

On 16 October 2029, I will – hopefully – become a member of the world’s fastest-growing demographic. By then, 1.4 billion people, a sixth of the world’s population, will be aged 60 or over. Assuming I make it, I can then expect to live for another 24 years.

I am the beneficiary of a global trend that started more than a century ago. A baby boy born in England in 1900 could expect to live to 44. By the time I was born, in 1969, that had risen to nearly 69. A baby boy born in England today can expect to live to 87, and a baby girl can expect to reach 90. Other places around the world, including lower-income countries, have also experienced rises in average life expectancy, buoyed by improved sanitation, nutrition and access to healthcare and education.

For the first time in human history, every person born today has a reasonable chance of celebrating their 60th birthday. But before we break out the cake and candles, we need to consider whether we will be able to blow them out.

For now, I’m in reasonably good health – but the longer my fellow soon-to-be sexagenarians and I live, the more likely we are to develop one or more age-related conditions. So are increases in life expectancy matched by increases in health expectancy? Or have we created a “nursing home world”?

These are surprisingly difficult questions to answer. But now, thanks to a new understanding of what health in later life looks like, we might finally have some answers. And not only is it positive news – mostly – we might also have a good idea of how we can stay healthier longer.

What is healthspan?

Gerontologists – researchers who study ageing – have long recognised that increasing average lifespan doesn’t automatically increase the number of healthy years of life. All those hard-won gains in life expectancy might merely extend the period of ill health, at great expense to individuals and healthcare systems.

“We all know that populations around the world are ageing rapidly,” says John Beard, professor of ageing at Columbia University in New York. “But what we’re not so clear on is, are those extra years being experienced in good health, better than previous generations, the same, or worse?” To answer that question, around 30 years ago, scientists working on ageing started using a concept called healthspan, which is defined as the number of years that a person lives in good health free from chronic illness or disabilities of ageing.

Assessing whether the beneficiaries of the longevity boom also enjoy an increased healthspan can yield depressing results. Last year, for example, Andre Terzic and Armin Garmany at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minnesota, published an analysis of 20 years of data from 183 countries in the World Health Organization’s Global Health Observatory. Using a measure of healthspan called health-adjusted life expectancy, they calculated the average discrepancy between lifespan and healthspan, what they called the “healthspan-lifespan gap”. They found that while average lifespans rose by 6.5 years between 2000 and 2019, from 66 to 72.5, healthspans didn’t keep pace, rising by only 5.4 years to 63.3. In other words, the healthspan-lifespan gap grew from 8.5 years to 9.6 years.

The largest gaps were in higher-income countries: 12.4 years in the US, 12.1 in Australia, 11.8 in New Zealand and 11.3 in the UK. Across the board, women lived longer than men, but also had a larger gap by more than two years. “These results underscore that around the world, while people live longer, they live a greater number of years burdened by disease,” the authors concluded.

That might sound like the issue is settled, but according to Beard and others, the focus on healthspan distorts the true picture. As a concept, healthspan suffers from a lack of clarity – for one thing, it seems to assume that only diseases of age diminish healthspan, without considering childhood or lifelong conditions. For another, it’s too binary: “With healthspan, you’re either healthy or you’re not healthy,” he says. “But health is not like life and death: life and death is black and white; health is a continuum.”

Studies like these, he says, tend to assume that healthspan ends abruptly with the diagnosis of a major age-related condition. But that fails to capture what impact the condition is having on quality of life. “The problem is, a diagnosis doesn’t really tell you much about people’s experience,” says Beard. “Three people can have the same condition and each have a very different experience.”

There are also medical interventions that can dramatically reduce the health effects of an age-related condition without curing it. “The one I often use is arthritis of the hip,” says Beard. “If people have a hip replacement, they’ve still got arthritis of the hip, but they can get around and do what they want to do.”

Functioning fine

Other studies have looked at health experience from a different angle: functionality. In other words, regardless of the presence or absence of disease, can people still get on with their daily lives?

“When we get older, sure, there are bad things that happen to our bodies,” says S. Jay Olshansky, a researcher on ageing at the University of Illinois Chicago. “But many folks that make it to older ages have found ways to adapt to these changes.”

That is a better way of assessing health, but studies that use functionality as a metric have a weakness, says Beard. “Most of those studies have only looked at very severe losses of functioning, using tests that were designed to decide whether people needed care,” he says, meaning they tend to underestimate the loss of functionality from less severe illness and disability.

What has also been missing is a concerted effort to measure day-to-day functioning in all older adults and how it compares with that of previous generations, says Beard. “So that’s what we tried to do.”

Stephan Schmitz

Over the past few years, he and his colleagues have pioneered a new approach to the problem using a concept called “intrinsic capacity”. The idea first surfaced in 2015 in the WHO’s World Report on Ageing and Health, and it is fundamentally different from what has gone before. Based not on the presence or absence of disease or disability, it instead assesses a person’s ability to do things and live life in a way they personally value. So, for example, somebody with minor hearing loss may not be diagnosed with an age-related disease but may be less able to interact socially than they would like. Their intrinsic capacity, therefore, would be lowered. Alternatively, someone diagnosed with a disease of old age, such as osteoarthritis – and so technically at the end of their healthspan – may be perfectly able to live a fulfilling life.

When it was first developed, the concept was only nebulously defined, but Beard and others have since put it on a firm scientific footing. It can now be measured objectively as a composite of people’s functional level in five domains: locomotion, cognition, vision and hearing, psychological health and general vitality. “These come from objective measures, clinical tests of each of these domains,” says Beard.

Clinicians and researchers using this model assign scores to the individual domains, weigh them appropriately and, from there, determine an overall numerical score. That makes intrinsic capacity a useful tool for measuring how well individual people are ageing: it has been validated as a predictor of mortality from respiratory disease, for example.

Perhaps more importantly, it also tells us how well we are ageing collectively, finally providing an answer to the big question: are increases in lifespan also delivering increases in how long we stay healthy?

Living longer, better

To find out, Beard and his colleagues reanalysed figures from two existing datasets. One was the English Longitudinal Study of Ageing, which followed four cohorts of adults who were born in 1920, 1930, 1940 and 1950 and recorded information that could be converted into scores of intrinsic capacity. The other was the China Health and Retirement Longitudinal Study, a similar project following three cohorts born in 1930, 1940 and 1950.

The aim of the analysis was to find out whether people in later cohorts entered older ages with higher intrinsic capacity and retained it for longer, on average. What they found blew their minds. “I was expecting there wouldn’t be much change, if anything,” says Beard. “But I have to say I was surprised. We found very stark improvements for almost all dimensions.”

In the English cohorts, they found that somebody born in 1950 had higher intrinsic capacity at 68, on average, than a 62-year-old who was born in 1940, for example. The data from China told a similar story. And that is only comparing people born 10 years apart. If you compare the English 1950 cohort to the 1920 one, the differences are even starker. “It’s more like 70 is the new 50-something,” says Beard. “I can tell you that with absolute certainty.”

The data also showed some evidence of a phenomenon called compression of morbidity, which refers to the conditions of old age being squeezed into the final year or two of life, rather than piling up slowly over a decade or more. “Clearly, we don’t want people living for a long period of their life in poor health where they can’t do what they need to do. But if you enter older age with a higher peak, there’s further to fall, and you can maintain a good level of functioning for a longer period of time,” he says.

The reasons for this gain aren’t hard to fathom – they are essentially the same as the reasons for increases in lifespan. These include higher-quality nutrition, especially in early life, as well as sanitation, better education, expanded access to medical care and lifestyle factors such as declining rates of smoking. The result is that the peak in a person’s intrinsic capacity, which for all cohorts occurred at around age 30, is higher for later generations than earlier ones. After that, it is mostly downhill, although cognitive capacity can continue to increase, and other domains can be improved with the right interventions. The most important takeaway, however, is that the higher the peak – the more intrinsic capacity at around age 30 – the longer it takes to descend.

Good news? Not so fast. The results only apply to the cohorts in the studies and can’t be generalised, although Beard says he expects to find similar improvements in datasets from other places. There are around 25 such studies from all over the world waiting to be analysed, he says.

It is also possible that the lower healthspan in older cohorts reflects early-life exposure to major upheavals, says Beard, such as the great depression, the second world war or the Chinese civil war, which ended in 1949. “It may be that the people born in 1950 had better nutrition, better learning environments, better everything,” he says.

Crucially, the results also don’t tell us what has happened to cohorts born after 1950. It is probable that the gains have slowed, stopped or even reversed as improvements in conditions such as access to education and healthcare have plateaued or dropped off, says Beard. “The explanations lie in the broader environment, and that’s important because, why would it continue to improve?” he says. “There may be a ceiling that we have probably attained. I look at my kids and I don’t think their nutrition is any better than mine was.”

People born in 1950 had a higher intrinsic capacity at 68, on average, than those born in 1940 had at 62 REUTERS/Gil Montano

There are also factors such as increased obesity, sedentarism and pollution that may be pushing the intrinsic capacity gains back – trends in life expectancy certainly appear to be going that way. It is possible that people born in the 1950s in higher-income countries may be a golden generation who will live the longest, healthiest lives in human history. Only time will tell: people born in 1960 are now knocking on the door of old age, so trends in that cohort will start to appear soon.

Improving intrinsic capacity

While we wait for more data on the fate of our collective intrinsic capacity, there are ways to boost your individual score. You can start by estimating it using the WHO’s downloadable Integrated Care for Older People (ICOPE) screening tool. It includes a basic checklist for assessing intrinsic capacity, including a series of questions and tests on the five domains. To a medical professional, failure on any of these would lead to further in-depth assessment, but this tool gives anyone a rough indication of their intrinsic capacity, says Beard.

After you have your assessment results, you can get to work improving your score. Even though many determinants of intrinsic capacity are laid down in early life, “it’s never too late”, says Beard. “There are no surprises – eat a healthy diet, maintain a healthy weight, don’t smoke, address stress. The field where there’s probably the most evidence is physical activity, both aerobic to maintain your fitness but also building and maintaining muscle mass, particularly as you get older.” Physical strength and fitness not only help maintain balance, which protects against falls, but also seem to reduce inflammation and the risk of chronic disease. (I know what I want for my 60th birthday: a set of dumbbells.)

Whether the trend continues or not, the recognition that our later years are becoming healthier is great news, and not only for me and the 1.4 billion people turning 60 with me. “That is a really excellent message to support combating ageism,” says Yuka Sumi, who runs the WHO’s ICOPE programme in Geneva, Switzerland. “Many in society think older people are care-dependent and frail and a burden. And not only the society, older people themselves. But actually our older population is getting healthier and healthier. The older person is a social asset and they contribute to society.”

Understanding our later years in terms of intrinsic capacity can and is changing how we approach ageing. “In my view, the concept of intrinsic capacity is revolutionary in our understanding of ageing,” says Olshansky.

“We now have the privilege of living into our 70s, 80s, 90s and beyond in ways that previous generations never had an opportunity to experience,” he says. “When we get older, sure, there are bad things that happen to our bodies. But we’ve found ways to push them aside so that they’re no longer relevant.”

It offers hope that ageing can be experienced with better quality of life and challenges negative stereotypes about older adults.
articles.personality_title: New measure shows people are ageing healthier and more active
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Over the past century, people around the world have been living longer thanks to better healthcare, nutrition, and living conditions. But living longer doesn’t always mean staying healthy longer. Scientists have struggled to understand if our extra years come with good health or more illness.

**What happened** – Researchers developed a new way to measure ageing called "intrinsic capacity." Instead of just looking at diseases, it assesses how well people function in five areas: movement, thinking, senses (like hearing and vision), mental health, and overall energy. Studies comparing different generations born between 1920 and 1950 in England and China showed that people born later have higher intrinsic capacity at older ages. For example, those born in 1950 at age 68 are healthier and more active than those born in 1940 at age 62.

**Impact** – This new measure reveals that people are not just living longer but also maintaining better health and independence for more years. Unlike earlier ideas focusing on the presence of disease, intrinsic capacity captures how well people can live their daily lives. It explains why many older adults today can enjoy activities and social connections despite some health issues. This understanding challenges stereotypes that ageing means inevitable decline.

**What's next step** – Scientists plan to analyze more data from around the world to see if this positive trend continues, especially for people born after 1950. Meanwhile, individuals can use tools from the World Health Organization to assess and improve their own intrinsic capacity through exercise, healthy diets, and avoiding smoking. Public health efforts may focus more on helping people maintain their ability to function well, not just on treating diseases.

**One-sentence takeaway** – New research shows that many people are ageing with stronger health and abilities than previous generations, highlighting the importance of daily functioning in understanding healthy ageing.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une nouvelle mesure révèle que les gens vieillissent en meilleure santé et plus actifs
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Au cours du siècle dernier, l'espérance de vie a augmenté dans le monde grâce à une meilleure santé, nutrition et conditions de vie. Mais vivre plus longtemps ne signifie pas toujours rester en bonne santé plus longtemps. Les scientifiques ont eu du mal à savoir si ces années supplémentaires sont vécues en bonne santé ou avec plus de maladies.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Des chercheurs ont créé une nouvelle façon de mesurer le vieillissement appelée « capacité intrinsèque ». Plutôt que de se concentrer uniquement sur les maladies, elle évalue comment les personnes fonctionnent dans cinq domaines : la mobilité, la mémoire, les sens (comme l'ouïe et la vue), la santé mentale et l'énergie générale. Des études comparant différentes générations nées entre 1920 et 1950 en Angleterre et en Chine montrent que les personnes nées plus tard ont une capacité intrinsèque plus élevée à un âge avancé. Par exemple, celles nées en 1950 à 68 ans sont en meilleure santé et plus actives que celles nées en 1940 à 62 ans.

**Impact** – Cette nouvelle mesure montre que les gens vivent non seulement plus longtemps, mais conservent aussi une meilleure santé et autonomie plus longtemps. Contrairement aux idées précédentes concentrées sur la présence de maladies, la capacité intrinsèque reflète la qualité de vie quotidienne. Elle explique pourquoi de nombreux seniors peuvent aujourd'hui profiter de leurs activités et relations sociales malgré certains soucis de santé. Cette compréhension remet en cause les stéréotypes sur le vieillissement.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques vont analyser plus de données mondiales pour vérifier si cette tendance positive se poursuit, notamment pour les personnes nées après 1950. En attendant, chacun peut utiliser des outils de l'Organisation mondiale de la santé pour évaluer et améliorer sa capacité intrinsèque grâce à l'exercice, une alimentation saine et l'absence de tabac. Les politiques de santé pourraient davantage soutenir le maintien des capacités fonctionnelles plutôt que seulement le traitement des maladies.

**Résumé en une phrase** – De nouvelles recherches montrent que de nombreuses personnes vieillissent avec une meilleure santé et plus d'autonomie que les générations précédentes, soulignant l'importance du fonctionnement quotidien pour comprendre un vieillissement en bonne santé.
articles.personality_title_es: Una nueva medida revela que las personas envejecen más saludables y activas
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – En el último siglo, la esperanza de vida ha aumentado en todo el mundo gracias a mejores cuidados de salud, nutrición y condiciones de vida. Pero vivir más tiempo no siempre significa mantenerse saludable más tiempo. Los científicos han tenido dificultades para entender si esos años extra se viven con buena salud o con más enfermedades.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores desarrollaron una nueva forma de medir el envejecimiento llamada "capacidad intrínseca". En lugar de fijarse solo en las enfermedades, evalúa qué tan bien las personas funcionan en cinco áreas: movimiento, pensamiento, sentidos (como audición y visión), salud mental y energía general. Estudios que compararon generaciones nacidas entre 1920 y 1950 en Inglaterra y China mostraron que las personas nacidas más tarde tienen mayor capacidad intrínseca en edades avanzadas. Por ejemplo, quienes nacieron en 1950 a los 68 años están más saludables y activas que quienes nacieron en 1940 a los 62.

**Impacto** – Esta nueva medida revela que las personas no solo viven más, sino que mantienen mejor salud e independencia por más años. A diferencia de ideas anteriores que se centraban en la presencia de enfermedades, la capacidad intrínseca refleja cómo las personas pueden llevar su vida diaria. Esto explica por qué muchos adultos mayores hoy disfrutan de actividades y conexiones sociales a pesar de algunos problemas de salud. Este entendimiento desafía estereotipos de que envejecer significa inevitable decadencia.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos planean analizar más datos globales para ver si esta tendencia positiva continúa, especialmente para quienes nacieron después de 1950. Mientras tanto, las personas pueden usar herramientas de la Organización Mundial de la Salud para evaluar y mejorar su propia capacidad intrínseca mediante ejercicio, dieta saludable y evitar fumar. Los esfuerzos de salud pública podrían enfocarse más en ayudar a mantener la capacidad funcional, no solo en tratar enfermedades.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Nuevas investigaciones muestran que muchas personas envejecen con mejor salud y capacidades que generaciones anteriores, destacando la importancia del funcionamiento diario para entender un envejecimiento saludable.

articles.title: Working past the age of retirement may improve your life satisfaction
articles.summary: Having a full-time job in later life has been linked to improved emotional, financial and general life satisfaction - but the results vary a lot between men and women
articles.content:
Having a full-time job in later life has been linked to improved emotional, financial and general life satisfaction - but the results vary a lot between men and women

Working later in life may not be a bad thing Kelvin Murray/Getty Images Source: Stone RF

Many people look forward to retirement, but continuing to work in later life may benefit your well-being – particularly if you are a man.

People are increasingly retiring later in life. A report by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) found that 28.9 per cent of 65 to 69 year olds across its 38 member states were still working in 2023, up from 15.9 per cent in 2000. But the impact of this on people’s happiness is little understood.

To get a grasp on the subject, Alisa Lewin at the University of Haifa and Haya Stier at Tel Aviv University, both in Israel, looked at social survey data collected by Israel’s Central Bureau of Statistics. They then compared the experiences of more than 3300 women and just over 2000 men who had reached their respective retirement ages of 62 and 67.

The pair found that both men and women were more likely to work full time if they had a lower household income. But the men who did so also rated their economic, family, emotional and general life satisfaction as equal to or even higher than those who didn’t work at all.

This was true regardless of the type of full-time work the men did. Meanwhile, the women only ever experienced improvements in family and economic satisfaction, and only if they held a professional, technical or managerial job.

The researchers say this could be because women may get more of a sense of purpose and fulfillment from other aspects of life. “Women might have other sources of emotional support or social engagement, so they don’t get it from work, they get it from somewhere else,” says Lewin.

“Men, even now, still perceive their role as looking after the family and achieving success at work – and it doesn’t just stop at 65 [the age people used to be forced to retire in the UK],” says Cary Cooper at the University of Manchester, UK.

The results were more mixed when assessing the well-being of participants who worked part time, with the results varying according to the type of job and how satisfaction is measured, as well as whether the participant was a man or a woman.

People whose initial well-being was good could be more inclined to work full time later in life, which might have swayed the findings. The results may also not apply to other countries or cultures, says Cooper.
articles.reasoning: The article presents research showing that working past retirement age can improve life satisfaction, emotional well-being, and financial security, especially for men. It highlights positive aspects of continued engagement in work later in life, which can inspire hope and curiosity about aging and well-being.
articles.personality_title: Working past retirement age linked to higher life satisfaction, especially for men
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – More people are choosing to work beyond traditional retirement ages, but how this affects their happiness is not well known. In many countries, retirement ages range around 62 for women and 67 for men.

**What happened** – Researchers in Israel studied over 5,300 people who reached retirement age, examining their work status and how satisfied they felt about their lives. They found that men working full time after retirement age reported equal or greater satisfaction in economic, family, emotional, and general life areas compared to those not working. Women showed improvement mainly in family and economic satisfaction, especially if they had professional or managerial jobs.

**Impact** – This study suggests that continuing full-time work in later life can support well-being, especially for men, by providing financial stability and emotional fulfillment. For women, work benefits were more limited and linked to job type, possibly because women often find emotional support outside work. This insight helps us understand how work contributes differently to life satisfaction depending on gender.

**What’s next step** – Future research may explore how these findings apply in other cultures and countries. Policymakers and employers might consider these differences when designing retirement and work options to improve later-life well-being.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Continuing full-time work beyond retirement age is associated with greater life satisfaction, particularly for men, while women’s benefits depend on job type and other life factors.
articles.personality_title_fr: Travailler après l’âge de la retraite améliore la satisfaction de vie, surtout chez les hommes
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – De plus en plus de personnes choisissent de travailler au-delà de l’âge traditionnel de la retraite, mais on connaît peu les effets sur leur bonheur. Dans de nombreux pays, l’âge de la retraite est autour de 62 ans pour les femmes et de 67 ans pour les hommes.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des chercheurs en Israël ont étudié plus de 5 300 personnes ayant atteint l’âge de la retraite, en examinant leur situation professionnelle et leur satisfaction de vie. Ils ont découvert que les hommes travaillant à temps plein après la retraite se déclaraient aussi satisfaits, voire plus, sur les plans économique, familial, émotionnel et global, comparés à ceux ne travaillant pas. Les femmes bénéficiaient surtout d’une meilleure satisfaction familiale et économique, surtout dans les emplois professionnels ou de direction.

**Impact** – Cette étude montre que continuer à travailler à temps plein plus tard dans la vie peut soutenir le bien-être, notamment chez les hommes, en apportant stabilité financière et épanouissement émotionnel. Pour les femmes, les bénéfices liés au travail sont plus limités et dépendants du type d’emploi, car elles trouvent souvent du soutien émotionnel ailleurs. Ces observations aident à comprendre l’influence différente du travail sur la satisfaction de vie selon le genre.

**Prochaine étape** – Les recherches futures pourraient vérifier si ces résultats se confirment dans d’autres cultures et pays. Les décideurs et employeurs pourraient adapter les options de retraite et d’emploi pour mieux améliorer le bien-être des seniors.

**En résumé** – Continuer à travailler à temps plein après l’âge de la retraite est associé à une plus grande satisfaction de vie, surtout chez les hommes, tandis que les avantages pour les femmes dépendent du métier et d’autres facteurs personnels.
articles.personality_title_es: Trabajar más allá de la edad de jubilación se asocia con mayor satisfacción de vida, especialmente en hombres
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Cada vez más personas optan por trabajar más allá de la edad tradicional de jubilación, pero se sabe poco sobre cómo esto afecta su felicidad. En muchos países, la edad de jubilación ronda los 62 años para mujeres y 67 para hombres.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores en Israel analizaron a más de 5,300 personas que alcanzaron la edad de jubilación, revisando su situación laboral y satisfacción con la vida. Encontraron que los hombres que trabajaban a tiempo completo después de la jubilación reportaban igual o mayor satisfacción económica, familiar, emocional y general que quienes no trabajaban. Las mujeres mejoraron principalmente en satisfacción familiar y económica, especialmente si tenían trabajos profesionales o gerenciales.

**Impacto** – Este estudio sugiere que continuar trabajando a tiempo completo en la vejez puede apoyar el bienestar, especialmente para los hombres, al brindar estabilidad financiera y realización emocional. Para las mujeres, los beneficios laborales fueron más limitados y dependieron del tipo de trabajo, probablemente porque suelen encontrar apoyo emocional fuera del trabajo. Este conocimiento ayuda a entender cómo el trabajo influye de manera distinta en la satisfacción vital según el género.

**Siguiente paso** – Futuras investigaciones podrían explorar si estos resultados aplican en otras culturas y países. Los responsables políticos y empleadores podrían considerar estas diferencias al diseñar opciones de retiro y trabajo para mejorar el bienestar en la vejez.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Trabajar a tiempo completo más allá de la edad de jubilación se asocia con mayor satisfacción de vida, especialmente en hombres, mientras que los beneficios para mujeres dependen del tipo de trabajo y otros factores personales.

articles.title: What scientists discovered about french fries and diabetes
articles.summary: French fries may be more than just a guilty pleasure—they could raise your risk of type 2 diabetes by 20% if eaten three times a week, while the same amount of boiled, baked, or mashed potatoes doesn’t appear to have the same effect.
articles.content:
Eating three servings of French fries a week is associated with a 20% increased risk of developing type 2 diabetes, but eating similar amounts of potatoes cooked in other ways -- boiled, baked or mashed -- does not substantially increase the risk, finds a study published by The BMJ on August 6.

What's more, replacing any form of potatoes with whole grains was associated with a lower type 2 diabetes risk, but swapping them for white rice was linked to an increased risk, the results show.

Potatoes contain several nutrients including fiber, vitamin C, and magnesium, but they also have a high starch content and therefore a high glycemic index, so have been linked to a higher risk of developing type 2 diabetes.

But neither the preparation method for potatoes nor specific foods that potatoes would replace have been considered, both of which are key to evaluating the overall health impact of potatoes.

To address this, researchers investigated the association between intake of potatoes prepared by different methods (boiled, baked, or mashed versus French fries) and risk of type 2 diabetes. They also looked at the impact on health of replacing potatoes with other major carbohydrates, such as whole grains and rice.

Their findings are based on more than 205,000 health professionals from three large US studies carried out between 1984 and 2021. Participants were free of diabetes, heart disease or cancer and completed detailed food questionnaires every four years.

During almost 40 years of follow up, 22,299 people were diagnosed with type 2 diabetes.

After adjusting for lifestyle and dietary factors related to diabetes risk, the researchers found that for every three weekly servings of total potato, the rate of type 2 diabetes increased by 5% and for every three weekly servings of French fries, the rate increased by 20%. However, similar intake of baked, boiled, or mashed potatoes was not associated with a significantly increased risk.

Replacing three weekly servings of total potato with whole grains lowered the type 2 diabetes rate by 8%. Substituting baked, boiled, or mashed potatoes with whole grains lowered the rate by 4%, and replacing French fries lowered the rate by 19%.

In contrast, replacing total potatoes or baked, boiled, or mashed potatoes with white rice was associated with an increased risk of type 2 diabetes.

This is an observational study so no firm conclusions can be drawn about cause and effect and the researchers can't rule out the possibility that other unmeasured factors may have influenced their results. Most participants were also health professionals of European ancestry, so findings may not apply to other populations.

Nevertheless, they conclude: "Our findings underscore that the association between potato intake and type 2 diabetes risk depends on the specific foods used as replacement. The findings also align with current dietary recommendations that promote the inclusion of whole grains as part of a healthy diet for the prevention of type 2 diabetes."

So, are potatoes back on the plate? Well, it depends, say researchers in a linked editorial, who note that it is important to consider preparation method and replacement food when guiding the public or informing policy.

They point out that with their relatively low environmental impact and their health impact, baked, boiled, or mashed potatoes can be part of a healthy and sustainable diet, though whole grains should remain a priority, but say future studies from more diverse populations that account for both preparation methods and substitution analysis are needed.
articles.reasoning: The article provides useful, evidence-based dietary insights that can help people reduce their risk of type 2 diabetes by choosing healthier potato preparation methods and substituting whole grains. It promotes informed, positive health choices and aligns with sustainable diet recommendations.
articles.personality_title: French fries linked to higher diabetes risk; other potato types are safer
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Potatoes are a common food rich in nutrients but high in starch, which can affect blood sugar. Scientists have long studied how eating potatoes relates to type 2 diabetes risk, but effects may vary depending on how potatoes are cooked and what foods they replace.

**What happened** – A study analyzed health data from over 205,000 people between 1984 and 2021. It found that eating French fries three times a week increased the chance of developing type 2 diabetes by 20%. However, eating the same amount of boiled, baked, or mashed potatoes did not raise diabetes risk significantly. The study also showed that swapping potatoes for whole grains lowered diabetes risk, while replacing them with white rice increased it.

**Impact** – This study provides clear evidence that how potatoes are prepared matters for diabetes risk. French fries, often fried in oil and salted, pose a higher risk, while other cooking methods are less harmful. It also highlights that choosing whole grains instead of potatoes can improve health outcomes. These details offer practical guidance for diet choices to lower diabetes risk.

**What's next step** – Researchers suggest more studies including diverse populations and considering food substitutions are needed. Meanwhile, public health advice may focus on recommending boiled, baked, or mashed potatoes rather than fried, and promoting whole grains as a healthy alternative.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Eating French fries regularly raises type 2 diabetes risk, but boiled, baked, or mashed potatoes do not, and replacing potatoes with whole grains can further reduce that risk.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les frites augmentent le risque de diabète, les autres pommes de terre sont plus sûres
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les pommes de terre sont un aliment courant riche en nutriments mais aussi en amidon, ce qui influence la glycémie. Les scientifiques étudient depuis longtemps le lien entre la consommation de pommes de terre et le risque de diabète de type 2, mais cet impact dépend du mode de cuisson et des aliments remplacés.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Une étude a analysé les données de santé de plus de 205 000 personnes entre 1984 et 2021. Elle a montré que manger des frites trois fois par semaine augmentait de 20 % le risque de développer un diabète de type 2. En revanche, consommer la même quantité de pommes de terre bouillies, cuites au four ou en purée n'augmentait pas le risque de façon significative. L'étude indique aussi que remplacer les pommes de terre par des céréales complètes réduit le risque, tandis que les remplacer par du riz blanc l'augmente.

**Impact** – Cette étude offre une preuve claire que le mode de préparation des pommes de terre est important pour le risque de diabète. Les frites, souvent cuites dans l'huile et salées, présentent un risque plus élevé, tandis que les autres méthodes sont moins nocives. Elle souligne aussi que choisir des céréales complètes à la place des pommes de terre améliore la santé. Ces informations sont des conseils pratiques pour réduire le risque de diabète.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs recommandent davantage d'études avec des populations variées et prenant en compte les substitutions alimentaires. En attendant, les conseils de santé publique pourraient privilégier les pommes de terre bouillies, cuites au four ou en purée plutôt que frites, et encourager les céréales complètes.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Manger régulièrement des frites augmente le risque de diabète de type 2, mais les pommes de terre bouillies, cuites au four ou en purée ne le font pas, et les remplacer par des céréales complètes réduit encore ce risque.
articles.personality_title_es: Las papas fritas aumentan el riesgo de diabetes, otras preparaciones son más seguras
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Las papas son un alimento común rico en nutrientes pero con alto contenido de almidón, lo que afecta el azúcar en sangre. Los científicos han estudiado por años cómo el consumo de papas se relaciona con el riesgo de diabetes tipo 2, pero este riesgo cambia según cómo se cocinen y qué alimentos se sustituyan.

**Qué pasó** – Un estudio analizó datos de salud de más de 205,000 personas entre 1984 y 2021. Encontró que comer papas fritas tres veces por semana aumentaba un 20 % el riesgo de desarrollar diabetes tipo 2. Sin embargo, consumir la misma cantidad de papas hervidas, al horno o en puré no aumentaba el riesgo significativamente. También mostraron que reemplazar papas por granos enteros disminuía el riesgo, mientras que sustituirlas por arroz blanco lo aumentaba.

**Impacto** – Este estudio muestra claramente que la forma de cocinar las papas influye en el riesgo de diabetes. Las papas fritas, que suelen ser fritas en aceite y saladas, presentan un mayor riesgo, mientras que las otras preparaciones son menos dañinas. Además, resalta que elegir granos enteros en lugar de papas puede mejorar la salud. Estos resultados ofrecen consejos prácticos para reducir el riesgo de diabetes.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores sugieren hacer más estudios con poblaciones diversas y que consideren sustituciones alimenticias. Mientras tanto, las recomendaciones de salud pública podrían enfocarse en insistir en papas hervidas, al horno o en puré en lugar de fritas, y en promover los granos enteros.

**Mensaje en una frase** – Comer papas fritas regularmente aumenta el riesgo de diabetes tipo 2, pero las papas hervidas, al horno o en puré no, y reemplazarlas con granos enteros puede reducir aún más ese riesgo.
